denies.doctrine: Authority of Scripture as the *ultimate* authority (sola Scriptura)
Justification by faith *alone* (sola fide)

Roman Catholic.note: Affirms inspiration/inerrancy and all classical Christological doctrines, but holds Scripture and Sacred Tradition together under the Magisterium and rejects sola fide.

denies.doctrine: Authority of Scripture as the *ultimate* authority (sola Scriptura)
Justification by faith *alone* (monergistic, forensic sense)

Eastern Orthodox.note: Affirms inspiration, Trinity, virgin birth, bodily resurrection, return; emphasizes Holy Tradition and a synergistic/theotic view of salvation rather than Protestant sola fide.

denies.doctrine: Nicene doctrine of the Trinity (one God in three co-equal, co-eternal persons)
Scripture as sole/ultimate authority (adds other scriptures; Bible ‘as far as correctly translated’)

Mormon (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter.note: Teaches a non-Nicene Godhead and qualifies biblical authority; also adds new canonical books.

denies.doctrine: Trinity
Full deity of Christ (teach Jesus is a created being/Michael)
Bodily resurrection of Jesus (teach a spiritual resurrection)

Jehovah's Witnesses.note: Affirm Jesus’ resurrection in a spiritual (not bodily) sense and reject Nicene trinitarianism.

denies.doctrine: Atonement as a once-for-all, substitutionary, objective work necessary/sufficient for reconciliation
Bodily (material) categories in resurrection (interprets resurrection/atonement metaphysically)

Christian Science.note: Reinterprets sin, atonement, and resurrection in metaphysical terms; downplays/denies materiality.

denies.doctrine: Trinity (holds ‘Oneness’/modalism—one divine Person who manifests as Father/Son/Spirit)

Oneness Pentecostalism (e.g., UPCI).note: Affirms Jesus’ deity and resurrection but rejects three co-eternal Persons.

denies.doctrine: Trinity
Pre-existence and full deity of Christ

Christadelphians.note: Non-trinitarian; teach Jesus is the Son of God but not co-eternal/consusbstantial with the Father.

denies.doctrine: Trinity
Full deity of Christ

Iglesia ni Cristo.note: Strict monotheism identifying only the Father as true God; Jesus is a man exalted by God.

denies.doctrine: Trinity (unitarian theism or non-theistic pluralism)
Inerrancy/ultimate authority of Scripture (non-creedal; Scripture not normative)
Full deity of Christ (varies; generally not required/affirmed)

Unitarian Universalism / Unitarian churc.note: Non-creedal movement; does not require affirmation of classical Christian dogmas.

denies.doctrine: Trinity of three Persons (teaches a ‘trinity’ as aspects within one Person, Jesus)
Forensic justification by faith alone (distinct soteriology)

Swedenborgian / New Church.note: Affirms one God in the person of the Lord Jesus Christ; rejects tri-personal distinctions.

denies.doctrine: Trinity
Full deity of Christ

The Way International.note: Explicitly rejects Nicene trinitarianism and the deity of Jesus.

denies.doctrine: Atonement as sufficient/completed by the cross alone
Nicene Trinity (non-orthodox view of God/Jesus)

Unification Church (Family Federation).note: Teaches Jesus’ mission/atonement were incomplete and reframes salvation around family ‘restoration’.

denies.doctrine: Trinity
Full deity and pre-existence of Christ

Biblical Unitarians / Church of God Gene.note: Affirm biblical authority but reject trinitarianism and Christ’s co-eternity.

denies.doctrine: Trinity as three co-equal Persons (reinterprets as ‘Mind-Idea-Expression’)
Unique deity of Christ (teaches ‘Christ’ as a divine potential in all)

Unity (Unity Church, New Thought).note: Metaphysical reinterpretation of Christian terms; not Nicene trinitarian or Chalcedonian.

denies.doctrine: Inerrancy and ultimate authority of Scripture (often rejected)
Virgin birth (commonly treated as non-essential or symbolic)
Bodily resurrection (sometimes reinterpreted as non-bodily)
Justification by faith alone (often rejected)

Progressive Christianity (movement—varie.note: Broad movement; many adherents/communities openly reject historic doctrines as non-essential.
